title: Worked Solution
text:
To determine the number of protons, neutrons, and electrons in an iodine anion (I⁻), we can break it down as follows:

$$1$$. $$	extbf{Number of protons}$$: The atomic number of iodine (I) is $$53$$, which means iodine has $$53$$ protons in its nucleus. The number of protons defines the element.

$$2$$. $$	extbf{Number of neutrons}$$: The mass number of iodine is given as $$127$$. The mass number is the sum of protons and neutrons:

$$	ext{Number of neutrons} = 	ext{Mass number} - 	ext{Number of protons}$$

$$	ext{Number of neutrons} = 127 - 53 = 74$$

$$3$$. $$	extbf{Number of electrons}$$: A neutral iodine atom has $$53$$ electrons, equal to the number of protons. However, since we are dealing with an iodine anion (I⁻), it has gained one extra electron:

$$	ext{Number of electrons} = 53 + 1 = 54$$

So, for the iodine anion (I⁻):
- $$	extbf{Protons}$$: $$53$$
- $$	extbf{Neutrons}$$: $$74$$
- $$	extbf{Electrons}$$: $$54$$
